div.head: Śākyaśrī, Śākyaśrībhadra (1127–1225)
div.p: Śākyaśrībhadra, “the great Kashmiri paṇḍita” as he was later known in Tibetan, rose to high positions as a monk and scholar in India. After serving as abbot of Nālandā, he also became the last abbot of Vikramaśīla, being forced to flee at the age of seventy-seven when the great monastic university was sacked by Muslim soldiers at the very start of the thirteenth century. He arrived in Tibet in 1204 along with other Indian paṇḍitas.

In the ten years he spent in Tibet, Śākyaśrībhadra became one of the most influential Indian paṇḍitas of the period. His “Kashmiri” monastic ordination lineage (kha che lugs) was adopted by the new schools of Tibetan Buddhism. He oversaw the translation of important works on philosophy, epistemology, and tantra, taught widely on all these topics, and established several new monasteries. Most significantly of all, perhaps, he was the teacher of Sakya Paṇḍita Kunga Gyaltsen (kun dga’ rgyal mtshan) and thus of huge importance not only to the Sakya lineage but also to the evolution of several major fields of scholarship and practice in Tibet.

As well as his major translation and teaching work, for traditions other than that of Sakya it is noteworthy that in the context of the polemics surrounding the authenticity of tantras brought to Tibet from India in the early translation period Śākyaśrībhadra confirmed the existence in Samye of a Sanskrit manuscript of the Guhyagarbhatantra, the principal tantra of Mahāyoga for the Nyingma tradition that had been strongly criticized by Gö Khugpa Lhetsé as not of Indian origin and without any Indian lineage.The Sakya patriarch Drakpa Gyaltsen (grags pa rgyal mtshan, 1147-1216) also recognized the authenticity of the Guhyagarbhatantra in his inventory of tantras, perhaps even before Śākyaśrībhadra’s confirmation. Whether or not he had seen the Sanskrit manuscript is not recorded.
After a decade in Tibet, he returned to his native Kashmir where he spent the last ten years of his long and productive life.
